summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2020 discussing victim notification letters for individuals related to the Jeffrey Epstein case. It involves coordination between the FBI Victim Services Division, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, and attorneys representing victims, specifically concerning which victims have been notified of case events and eligibility for services.

persons.context: A trial attorney from Edwards Pottinger Lax, representing victims, who is requesting victim notification letters for her clients and coordinating with the FBI and USAO.

persons.context: Mentioned as having had a telephone conversation with an FBI contact; appears to be an attorney or representative involved in the victim notification process.

persons.name: Maria Kelljchian
persons.context: An FBI Victim Specialist from the New York Office, involved in the correspondence regarding victim notification letters.

connections.description: Henderson, a victims' attorney, is emailing Kelljchian, an FBI Victim Specialist, regarding victim notification letters for her clients.
Both are involved in representing victims and coordinating with law enforcement on notification matters, as referenced in their conversations.

events.title: Email Coordination on Victim Notifications
events.description: Series of emails discussing the status of victim notification letters sent by the FBI and USAO to victims of Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
425 North Andrews Avenue, Suite 2, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33301
keyFacts: The FBI Victim Services Division and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York were coordinating in July 2020 to determine which victims of Jeffrey Epstein had received official notification letters regarding case events and eligibility for services.
Attorney Brittany Henderson, representing multiple victims, provided lists of clients to the FBI, separating those who had misplaced notification letters from those who needed interviews.
The email chain references the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) as a source for identifying some victims.
A key point of confusion was that, per a VSD Notification Report, only one person was recorded as having received a notification, which the sender found alarming and potentially incorrect.
The correspondence indicates the investigation was still considered open as of July 2020, with victim notification procedures being carefully managed by prosecutors.
